#Text=Measure Market Volatility
#Text=Volatility in financial markets is a concern among finance professionals , traders and investors , and anybody else looking at the ongoing market situation for a particular region or exchange .
#Text=But volatility is a word that many individuals use in many different contexts .

#Text=If you need to measure market volatility as an investor or anyone up with a stake in changes to a financial market , here are some of the best ways to examine volatility , or changes in market price , according to some experienced professionals and others .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Choose a time frame in which to examine market volatility .
#Text=Volatility is a variable that is only accurate within a certain time frame .

#Text=That 's why most brokerage accounts and other services provide time adjustable charts that show how an asset , a market or a collection of financial products has changed over a specific amount of time .
#Text=Use formulas to further define volatility .
#Text=Within your given time frame , you can make use of simple or more complex formulas to calculate volatility technically .
#Text=Use an index to look at how volatility has affected multiple assets .
#Text=Single stocks or financial products have their own specific volatility within a market , but traders often use an index to define volatility for multiple stocks or products .
#Text=An index is simply a collection of values for stocks , funds and other products that provides a total change in price .
#Text=One of the most basic formulas for calculating volatility is the following : range multiplied by ( maximum price minus minimum price ) for your time period .
#Text=Other more complex formulas like VIX or Beta help finance professionals and others understand more about how prices are changing within a given market .
#Text=Calculate percentage changes .

#Text=Using individual assets or the index tools mentioned above , take a look at how much a price has changed over time and calculate that as a percentage of the total value to find a " total volatility " that you can use to predict future markets .
#Text=Assess various stock index tools to see how they can help you measure volatility .

#Text=For example , in the American market , the Dow Jones industrial average , a collection of blue-chip stocks , has its own volatility calculations that can help you better understand where a market has been and where it is going .
#Text=Evaluate moving averages .
#Text=For many traders , it 's not enough just to see how much a price has changed .
#Text=It 's also important to see which direction that change has gone within a greater context .
#Text=Even if you have identified your specific time frame for volatility , you may want to go back further and look at how the stock or other asset has changed over a greater time frame .
#Text=A moving average helps financial professionals to do this by providing an average price for the asset over a longer period of time such as 1 year .
#Text=Account for market sentiments .
#Text=Use random number method like Random Number tables or concept of ' Brownian Motion for financial analysis ' especially in case of Stock market volatility .
